db:article.db:para: You should call the following CMake commands to use the Qt6::Protobuf module in your project:
db:article.db:programlisting:
find_package(Qt6 REQUIRED COMPONENTS Protobuf)
target_link_libraries(mytarget PRIVATE Qt6::Protobuf)
db:article.db:para: You can use the qt_add_protobuf CMake command to implicitly call Qt Protobuf code generation for your project.

db:section.db:title: Using qt_add_protobuf
db:section.db:programlisting:
cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.16...3.22) project(MyThings)
find_package(Qt6 REQUIRED COMPONENTS Protobuf) qt_standard_project_setup()
qt_add_protobuf(MyMessages GENERATE_PACKAGE_SUBFOLDERS PROTO_FILES path/to/message.proto path/to/other_message.proto PROTO_INCLUDES /path/to/proto/include )
qt_add_executable(MyApp main.cpp)
target_link_libraries(MyApp PRIVATE MyMessages)
db:section.db:para: In the example above, we generate a library called MyMessages, which contains the message types defined in the paths passed to the PROTO_FILES option. The GENERATE_PACKAGE_SUBFOLDERS option to generate a folder structure for the generated files. And the PROTO_INCLUDES option tells protoc to look for dependencies or imports in the specified directories. We create a target for an executable called MyApp, which we link to the MyMessages library.
